Topic.Title: Haswell

Message.Msg: AMD Phenom II X2 555 Black Edition Callisto 3.2GHz Socket AM3 80W Dual-Core Desktop Processor - C3 AMD Phenom II X2 560 Black Edition Callisto 3.3GHz Socket AM3 80W Dual-Core Desktop Processor HDZ560WFGMBOX You're talking about 4 watts? This is your idea of a strong sell? Let's be clear about what you're talking about You're talking about maximum power consumption of the processor. The Phenom may idle at higher rates than Haswell. More importantly it's about performance per watt. You are comparing a 4th generation core processor to one AMD came out with back in 2009. Check the Newegg SKU's they don't sell it anymore. But for the idiots who want to overclock this AMD processor to get the mildest amount of performance it's going to be over Haswell's TDP ALL THE TIME. "Dude, I got my processor to 4GHZ" Congratulations, you've got a souped up 4 cylinder car. Haswell is a turbo charged V12 with 4 cylinder fuel efficiency.

Topic.Title: Andrew Tonner is an idiot...

Message.Msg: He looks so young, was probably 10 years old when AMD and Intel were truly competitive, and with no real tech background (analysts aren't technologists) he can't comprehend the coming storm that is Intel with a true focus on mobile. He also can't comprehend that Apple is now so big that it needs to innovate on the same industry shocking scale as with the iPhone just to get back to growth, and that margin shrinkage will more than counter any top line growth going forward. I have no position in AAPL but have been following them since the early Mac days and even implemented a rollout of Mac OSX (the original version) many moons ago. Back then only the imaging and advertising gurus used Macs, so it wasn't a huge rollout by any means, nor was it simple since they insisted on using non-standard network protocols.

Topic.Title: Tell me your predictions for June:

Message.Msg: This is purely a guess jaded by years of market watching. It seems that when everybody "knows" that a stock is ready to pop and poised for gains, somehow it either stays flat or declines. My money is placed for a fairly flat June, with expectations that it will start to creep through July and August into back to school sales. Depending on retail channel reports in late August, it may start to go higher, but the real pop will be on earnings in October... That said, I hold a couple of in the money Jan 2014 and Jan 2015 calls for insurance in case I'm wrong, but... I don't think it breaks $25 pre June option expiration... In July I don't see it breaking $26... In late August, after option expiration with strong retail channel checks it may see a bump towards $27 And if earnings play out with positive guidance in October we can see $ 27+ JMHO, and I'd love to see my predictions labeled as too conservative... Many thanks to all who post the technical stuff... I'm just a numbers guy who's weak on the semi knowledge...

Topic.Title: Andrew Tonner is an idiot...

Message.Msg: My son , an avid apple fan for his whole post teen life, is now a professional...he now says the only serious computing is done on x86 based hardware. He is buying large Intel inside systems for his own company (for video editing). The PC-Desktop is a sedan or an SUV, while the tablet is a sportscar. You'll never see one replace the other. Tonner is a mindless parrot..."PC is Dead" what garbage. Motley Fool is utter excrement. No credentials at all. They post titles that make you think they may be objective, or even supportive of INTC, only to suck you in to the usual bashing balderdash. I wish there was a "super-ignore" feature for all Motley Fools articles.

Topic.Title: Tell me your predictions for June:

Message.Msg: You'll see no significant breakout until it becomes clear that earnings and revenues are going to start to grow again. I cannot predict that. For all I know Intel will have to sacrifice margins to establish a stronghold in mobile. That could postpone financial growth for an indefinite period. While I DO NOT subscribe to the Covello-Shah view of armageddon, you have to acknowledge where that is coming from: it represents the notion that Intel growth into mobile will be expensive and not necessarily all that lucrative. The smartphone chip market in tota is only about 10% of INTC total revenues, as I understand it. At what cost? The math makes me a little nervous about the new CEO and Presidemt...they seem obsessed with mobile, what may turn out to be a false premise. Ottelini's longer term "fundamentals" view made more sense to me. More like a respected company with standards rather than a "tabloid." I believe the only true growth in E and R can come from the internet of everything and success of PC's-Desktops in the ultrabook era and demand for servers, which is predicted to grow well over 10% in coming years, . This is why INTC wants to launch internet video...to stimulate the demand for server bandwidth. So...in guessing a high for the year we have to bet on hubris, or on the implications of Haswell family for the core business. There's eternal drag on INTC stock pps. So I'll go with $27 for the end of year...I'll have to buy back my January 2014 30's leaps.

Topic.Title: Tell me your predictions for June:

Message.Msg: the problem with being a numbers guy is that you miss structural changes in the technology. the problem with being a structural guy is that you miss the psychology that (unfortunately has proven useful) underpins the market. The analysts are great at telling you who is right after the fact. Let's hope I'm right.... but like I tell my wife, if it was easy, we'd all be rich.

Topic.Title: Why I never bought an iPad

Message.Msg: iPads and ARM-Android tablets largely offer duplicate capability as their respective smartphones only with larger displays. While an increase in display size offers modest utility over their small cousin, the redundant capability is why the tablet market hasn't grown much faster already, particularly for those that own one of the larger Android smartphones. The new class of Intel tablets capable of running a professional 64 bit OS plus Android enables Intel devices to offer far more value and utility than anything before in the tablet format. Previous tablets were too limited to be really interesting - the Intel tablets I'll buy.

Message.Title: the Exynos 5 Octa, the chip may not be all it’s cracked up to be.
Message.Msg: From the Android Authority; The Exynos 5 Octa and the State of Samsung SoCs by Daniel Charlton on June 2, 2013 8:47 am "All of this leads up to the Exynos 5 Octa and the Galaxy S4. The Octa is used in the GT-I9500 variant of the Galaxy S4 and is supposed to solve the problem of Cortex-A15 power consumption by using ARM’s big.LITTLE architecture. big.LITTLE allows the use of two core clusters, one for high-performance tasks and one for low-performance tasks. In the Octa, this is a quad-core Cortex-A15 cluster and a quad-core Cortex-A7 cluster, all built on 28nm. In big.LITTLE, there are supposed to be three modes for managing threads across all of the cores in both clusters. Evidence thus far suggests that the Octa really only supports one of these modes – the least efficient. Even worse, it appears that this limitation is due to crippled hardware in the SoC and not something that can be fixed in software" "According to Samsung, there is no hardware problem at all and the company chose cluster-migration because it “show[s] increased performance/efficiency.” But the statement does not match up with most people’s understanding of ARM’s big.LITTLE architecture. Moreover, ARM demonstrated core-migration working on a pre-release version of the Octa. And Samsung’s released kernel source code for the Octa includes the drivers for core-migration. But that code does not work in the final release version of the Octa and Samsung has been coy in giving a straight answer. Based on this, Linus Torvalds wrote:“quite frankly, the fact that the Exynos 5 currently only works in ‘either or’ configuration almost certainly means that there is something fundamentally wrong with the hardware design, to the point where no amount of ‘complex patches’ can fix it.” While this certainly makes it seem that Samsung has done something wrong in the Octa, the chip is still entirely based on designs from ARM. Torvalds goes on to point out, "

Topic.Title: the Exynos 5 Octa, the chip may not be all it’s cracked up to be.

Message.Msg: continued; "Torvalds goes on to point out, he has “very little reason to believe that ARM engineers got their cache handling right. They've never done that before. They've had some of the crappiest caches on the planet.” So, it is very likely that the problem is not even inside Samsung’s control."

Topic.Title: the Exynos 5 Octa, the chip may not be all it’s cracked up to be.

Message.Msg: I will be interested to see how they approach cache coherency. Moving the data around the system to remain coherent and wiggles some big transistors. Intel made a big change in the way they handle coherency in the 45nm Nehalem CPU which resulted in a big performance jump. Intel likely has a couple of patents on that design that will be generating some revenue if someone chooses to use. The other problem that will be interesting will be, if they operate in 4-big or in 4-little mode, what does the scheduler look like? When I push the start button does a little wake up or does a big wake up. If I start an app, does it chose the littles or does it chose the bigs? If I have 4 app running and 1 would like a big core and 3 would work fine with little cores, what does it chose. These are very hard problems to solve and ARM and those who design their own versions will have to do a lot of head scratching.

Topic.Title: the Exynos 5 Octa, the chip may not be all it’s cracked up to be.

Message.Msg: The reason they chose to do it this way, is because the A15 does not scale very well along the performance-power curve. The other big problem they have with core migration, is that in addition to context switching, is that apps have to be compiled for the lowest common instruction set, limiting instruction set extensions.

Message.Title: What We Know Now
Message.Msg: What we know now is that ARM is having multiple problems in competing with Intel. On the performance side, we are learning that ARM simply doesn't ramp very well as they try to counter Intel's superior performance. Samsung turning to Intel is good evidence of this. The big.little technology was nothing more than what ARM has to consider as a band-aid due to its lack of state-of-the-art fabrication. And we already know about the vast array of problems with ARM trying to move just a half-step to FinFET. The half-step is an effort by ARM to prevent Intel from just leaving them in the dust as they cycle down to 10, 7 and 5nm production. Intel is already actively working on 10nm production, due in 2015. If you throw in the problems ARM is having and will have with EUV and 450mm wafers, it's apparent that the technology and manufacturing hurdles are immense. With that huge P/E ratio, they cannot afford even a single stumble...

Topic.Title: Tell me your predictions for June:

Message.Msg: "You'll see no significant breakout until it becomes clear that earnings and revenues are going to start to grow again." [Well, there is some pretty significant evidence that this might not be true if what you are talking about is reported earnings and revenue. The market is usually forward looking. It hasn't been the case with Intel - the market has been totally braindead but there are signs this is changing. We have already seen a break-down with ARM - twice recently and the latest is already over 5 bucks.This is almost totally from recognition of the increased competition from Intel. We have Altera and Samsung as clear indicators of the changing landscape. That ARM can drop by five bucks without Intel moving up by a large portion of that is a disconnect. ARM's loss is Intel's gain. More and more we are seeing signs of the tipping point and that it is being reached faster and faster. It's not about the delta - it's about the delta of the delta. We don't need quarterly results to continue this trend. Obviously ARM didn't need quarterly results for the bottom to start dropping out. We do need some huge press for it to happen. And that's what we are getting now. Really huge press relating to Haswell, Computex and the Samsung tablet deal. It could easily coalesce enough to result in a break out in the short-term. Will it happen? Dunno. But it would be silly to say that it couldn't...]

Topic.Title: the Exynos 5 Octa, the chip may not be all it’s cracked up to be.

If it's an ARM problem then you can forget doing any serious large memory ARM SMP server systems. ARM flaps its gums a lot but they are not looking too smart at the moment. Also having Torvalds publicly disparage your architecture is not good PR, he has slagged off Itanium for years which has not done it any PR favors.

Message.Title: More details on Intel's Haswell CPUs released
Message.Msg: This may seem like an odd time to announce a new processor, but it's smack in the middle of the giant Computex conference taking place in Taipei, Taiwan. There's no "post-PC" talk at that show, Computex is all about the PC, and that's where Intel took almost all of the wraps off Haswell, its next generation of Core branded CPUs. All told the company is introducing 12 desktop and 10 notebook high-end quad-core chips in the Core i7 and Core i5 families. The differentiations are mostly along target platforms and clock speeds, as these are all quad-core CPUs with HyperThreading. The price is around the $300 range, which is in line with typical upper-end CPUs. There will be a second announcement as relates to ultrabooks, the Core i3, Pentium and Celeron lines in a few days. [This is a great move as it will extend the news cycle] The GPU portion of things is the overwhelming story here. [Well, that and the power efficiency but this was written from a gamer's perspective] Haswell comes with a total of five GPU cores on the CU die, up from three on Ivy Bridge. The big deal is Iris, a separate GPU that will co-exist with the HD graphics that currently ships with Ivy Bridge. From ITWorld

Message.Title: Intel Licensing Deal with Broadcom
Message.Msg: Haswell also introduces WiDi 4.1, an upgrade to Intel's wireless video transmission protocol. Intel now has Broadcom as a licensee and there will be more HDTVs from LG and Toshiba and devices from vendors like Lenovo, Netgear Actiontec and QVOC. From ITWorld [Bump for the licensing deal with Broadcom...]

Topic.Title: More details on Intel's Haswell CPUs released

Message.Msg: "Another graphic feature is QuickSync, which will improve MPEG video encoding and decoding as well as video playback. A Haswell-based laptop could get as much as nine hours of HD video playback."

Message.Title: Intel to cooperate with retail channels to show Haswell-based WiDi, touch control technologies
Message.Msg: In order to promote its Haswell platform, Intel will cooperate with retail network operators in the Taiwan market to showcase Haswell-based Wireless Display (WiDi) and touch control-supporting technologies at major retail outlets starting the third quarter, according to industry sources, adding that this is part of Intel's marketing subsidization for Haswell. From digitimes

Topic.Title: Intel Licensing Deal with Broadcom

Message.Msg: Intel relaxed the Ultrabook spec to allow Broadcom licensed WiDi. Could this be Intel's attempt to encourage increased licensing revenues. "Note that Connected Standby Ultrabooks will have to have the OS on an SSD due to Microsoft’s requirements. USB3.0 is a given as the controller is built into the chipset. WiDi support means either an Intel Ethernet module or one using the licensed technology. Broadcom is the only third party we know of that has licensed WiDi so far." Ultrabook (3rd Gen) Requirements: •Max thickness 23mm (was 19mm for pure laptops) •Must be hardware ready for voice command. (We assume array microphones for beam forming or noise cancelation) •6 hours of HD video playback •9 hours Windows 8 idling time •Wake from sleep in three seconds •WiDi support •Touchscreen •Antivirus and antimalware software to be preinstalled. Identity Protection Technology support. Intel Releases Updated but Fuzzy Ultrabook Requirements ultrabooknewsDOTcom/2013/06/01/intel-releases-updated-but-fuzzy-ultrabook-requirements/

Topic.Title: the Exynos 5 Octa, the chip may not be all it’s cracked up to be.

Message.Msg: It's the other way around, big/little allowed the A15 to be so powerful/power hungry. Big/little is't a hack, it's an integrate part of ARM's design and it's spreads into the next generation CPU design (and it's GPU's). If the interconnect doesn't work, then ARM have problems. Any CPU big/little config have the same exact ISA allowing extremely quick context switches.

Topic.Title: the Exynos 5 Octa, the chip may not be all it’s cracked up to be.

Message.Msg: There is a readable white paper floating about that describes in detail everything you wanted to know about how CCI works - if it works:) In the S4 there is no (kernel) scheduler changes for big little. It's ether the quad A7 or quad A15 that is active, the kernel doesn't get involved, it's handled in hardware. There have been recent changes submitted to the linux kernel scheduler to handle the other use cases of big/little but as the Android kernel is so far behind mainline, it's unlikely the S4 would ever see them... With the new kernel all 8 cores could be active, with the scheduler choosing the 'correct' core for the workload.

Topic.Title: the Exynos 5 Octa, the chip may not be all it’s cracked up to be.

Message.Msg: It appears that the silicon has the chip start operation in A7 mode until it detects some task migration stimulus. Migrating from A7 to A15 takes about 20,000 cycles to transfer state. I am going to have to dig a little further to see if they estimate the cycle cost of warming the new caches. It seems like so far that they are just putting the 20,000 cycles overhead on the state transfer. At 1GHz, you have a 20 microsecond state transfer time to the big CPU. You then have some time before the inbound cache is reasonably warmed up. The A15 is powered up. A15 caches are invalidated to clean them. A15 snooping is enabled A15 is provided with the register state of the outbound task A15 begins normal operation. A7 stays powered up to allow A15 data snoops to satisfy the data accesses from the A7 cache instead of memory. Detecting the convert stimulus is the part I am interested in now.

Topic.Title: Barrons Article on Intel

Message.Title: Forbes: MSI GT70 Dragon Edition Review: The First Haswell And GTX 780M Laptop Is A Hit
Message.Msg: When showing MSI’s GT70 Dragon Edition 2 laptop to friends and internet acquaintances, the reaction to its bold design have been seated firmly in one of two departments: Love it/hate it. Its brushed aluminum chassis is infused with a candy apple red and adorned with a stylish dragon tattoo on its wrist rest and lid. Depending on who you ask, it’s either striking and stylish or gaudy and extreme. One thing is certain: MSI has stuffed the GT70 with so much next-generation silicon and hardware that it’s screaming for your attention inside and out. The Specs: At its heart is the new fourth-generation (Haswell) Intel INTC +0.27% Core i7-4700MQ with a base clock of 2.40GHz, though it ramps up to 3.4GHz dynamically as needed. The next-gen hardware continues with NVIDIA’s GTX 780M, packed with 4GB of 256-bit GDDR5, a mobile graphics card which, as you’ll see below, makes the case for the GT70 becoming a desktop replacement. Also standard is 32GB of RAM and the GT70 Dragon Edition’s secret weapon: A 384GB boot drive comprised of three 128GB mSATA III SSDs in Super RAID 0. MSI claims insane read speeds of 1500MB/s. In the image below, the left chart depicts read/write speeds for a single OCZ Vertex 3 SSD present in my personal rig. On the right, actual results from my GT70 review sample. While it didn’t reach 1500MB/s, what it did achieve is nothing short of impressive: Suffice to say, installing frequently played games and creativity software on this drive results in ridiculously improved load times. Rounding out the specs is a 6x Blu-Ray read/write combo drive, a 1TB secondary hard drive, Killer Wireless-N gaming card with Bluetooth 4.0, and a beautiful full HD 17.3″ matte LCD screen. Said screen can be complimented by three external displays, as the rear of the laptop hides Mini-DisplayPort, HDMI, and VGA outputs. All displays — including the GT70′s internal one — can be in use simultaneously. I love matte displays and this one is premium with great color depth...

Topic.Title: Barrons Article on Intel

Message.Msg: I put my order for 1000K shares today.

Topic.Title: Forbes: MSI GT70 Dragon Edition Review: The First Haswell And GTX 780M Laptop Is A Hit

Message.Msg: More: I didn’t spend much time with synthetic benchmarks; the SSD test and the above PCMark 7 test were proof positive that the GT70 was a speed demon. I was pleasantly surprised at what Intel’s HD Graphics 4600 could do on its own without NVIDIA’s help, but after days of gaming (tough job I know), the power of the GTX 780M with its 4GB of GDDR5 left me with a warm fuzzy feeling. A dragon may grace the GT70′s brushed aluminum chassis, but thankfully you won’t get burned. After 5 hours of running Heaven 4.0 on its most demanding settings, the internal GPU temperature maxed out at 91 degrees Celsius, but the heat dissipation didn’t reflect that temperature. MSI’s Cooler Booster 2 tech makes a genuine impact by connecting the CPU and GPU cooling systems via a thermal bridge. Once either component gets hotter, the system transfers the heat to the opposite side faster. In simpler terms, even lefties aren’t going to get their mouse hand fried by the exhaust, and the external keyboard temperature remained within levels that wouldn’t impact gaming. I honestly expected the system to melt with so much next-generation silicon inside, but the chassis didn’t even approach levels I’d call hot, even after stress-testing the system.

Topic.Title: Forbes: MSI GT70 Dragon Edition Review: The First Haswell And GTX 780M Laptop Is A Hit

Message.Msg: Still more: The Bottom Line: If you do take the plunge on the GT70 Dragon Edition 2, consider buying from PowerNotebooks instead of directly through MSI. The guys at PowerNotebooks strip out all of MSI’s bloatware (Norton? No thanks!) and add a wealth of choices like preferred version of Windows OS, and the option of swapping out your optical drive for an additional SSD or HDD. The onslaught of Haswell and GTX 780M-equipped notebooks is only just beginning, and there will be no shortage of compelling hardware to evaluate. But MSI’s GT70 Dragon Edition 2 is first out of the gate, and while it comes with a steep pricetag, it more than justifies it in performance and features. If portable gaming is your gig and the bold design choices appeal to you, then you can’t go wrong here.

Topic.Title: Forbes: MSI GT70 Dragon Edition Review: The First Haswell And GTX 780M Laptop Is A Hit

Message.Msg: "The onslaught of Haswell and GTX 780M-equipped notebooks is only just beginning, and there will be no shortage of compelling hardware to evaluate."

Message.Title: In Advance of Computex
Message.Msg: PC manufacturers announced machines that are cooler, smaller and faster Sunday in advance of Computex. The new machines feature Intel's speedier fourth-generation Core processors, code-named Haswell, which Intel announced Saturday. Asus, Cyberpower, and MicroCenter announced all-in-ones, gaming laptops and desktops running Haswell, while major PC makers like Dell, Acer, and others expected to follow with more Haswell announcements in the coming days. Many new PCs will be on display at the Computex trade show in Taipei, which opens Tuesday. The announcements came on the heals of Intel announcing its first fourth-generation quad-core Core i7 and i5 chips based on Haswell. Intel is expected to announce more Haswell processors at Computex. From PCWorld

Topic.Title: In Advance of Computex

Message.Msg: You are going to have ONE FUN WEEK!!! Those negative on INTC are going to struggle.

Message.Title: Origin PC lineup makes the leap to Haswell
Message.Msg: Origin PC makes a point of embracing game-friendly technology as soon as it arrives, and you'd better believe it's welcoming Haswell-based processors with open arms: virtually all of its computer line is making the jump to the faster Intel hardware. The raw CPU power is the main highlight for the Chronos, Genesis and Millennium desktops, while those buying the larger EON15-S and EON17-S laptops get a few additional treats... From Engadget

Topic.Title: Why I never bought an iPad

Message.Msg: intel toast - writing is on the wall.

Message.Title: Haswell mania begins
Message.Msg: Acer Aspire S7 and S3 hands-on: Haswell mania begins The Aspire S7 was, for many of us, the best ultrabook of the Ivy Bridge CPU generation. No Windows laptop before it had ever been quite so thin, beautiful and robust, and while the S7 could clearly match aesthetics with Apple's MacBook Air, it also had a distinctive design of its own. Looking to build on that success, Acer today introduced an upgraded Aspire S7-392 ultrabook, powered by Intel's latest Haswell chips, as well as a new Aspire S3 line that compromises a bit on style to deliver more power. From theverge

Message.Title: Intel Haswell Launched: 5 Things You Need to Know
Message.Msg: Improved Battery Life Graphics Powerhouse A Focus on 2-in-1 Devices Improved WiDi Support New Ultrabook Standards Intel’s Haswell chips also bring with them a new set of standards for defining Ultrabooks. In order for a fourth-generation Core processor-powered notebook to be considered an Ultrabook, it must offer WiDi, voice control and sport a touch screen display. The system should also be able to wake from sleep in less than 3 seconds, offer more than 7 days of standby battery life, be able to idle for 9 hours on Windows 8, and provide more than 6 hours of HD video playback. Beyond that, an Ultrabook should also offer anti-virus and anti-malware protection, include Intel’s Anti-Theft and Identity Protection Technology and be less than 23mm thick. As part of its focus on 2-in-1 devices, the Ultrabook standard will also include more convertible designs. From lpatopmag
